page.title: 02CLAYPOLE-ORIGINS
page.content: In the Lincolnsire Domesday survey of 1086 the village was called Claipol which perhaps means the form of settlement on clay. Claypole, as it is spelled today, is the largest of our three villages and in the census of 1981 had a population of 604 and had 215 households. There have been no great changes since then. The main street runs from the river bridge to the railway level crossing, a distance of about one mile or 1.6 kilometres. There are five short by-lanes. The houses are generally of the red brick and pantile type, a characteristic that is being maintained in new building.
